### Terms

Freelance vs consulting vs contracting

Marketing â†’ Sales

Potential Leads â†’ Leads â†’ Deals â†’ Clients

### Common questions

how do I start?

how do I get my first clients?

should I do social media, or a website?

what do I do when someone asks â€œwho have you worked with?â€ but Iâ€™m just getting started?

Maybe I should get testimonials - what are they for and how do I get good ones?

Iâ€™m not a salesperson or marketer by background - how do I even think about these?

How do I set prices?

/Defining-Your-Services.title: Defining Your Services
/Defining-Your-Services.content:
Your first year you might "try on" a lot of services -- learning which things there is "market appetite" for, and which things you like to do. My first year I had ~30 services that I offered or got paid to do, or was considered for. It's dizzying to try and do too many, but I learned a lot about the market and about myself!

Eventually most people decide to offer fewer services to specialize in. This helps you with your own focus, but it has an even stronger effect for marketing. The more specific your services are, the easier it is for people to think of you when your services are needed -- and this includes  both potential clients directly and people who would connect you to those potential clients.

As my friend Andrea Goulet often says, "the riches are in the niches" (riches rhymes with niches if you force it! hah).

### Starter Service

-   Most places want to â€˜try it before the buy itâ€
    -   or more often try it (paid) before they buy a lot of it
    -   this reduces the risk of buying a big expensive service
-   What services can you over a small amount of that helps them see the value of more?
    -   For me, workshops: a free workshop (granted to someone who attends a public workshop of mine, to take to their company)
    -   For me, coaching: Coaching comes up in some way when I interview people through an Organizational Assessment â€” people who would want coaching often volunteer for this. Iâ€™m not explicitly coaching in these, but they can see my style, how I listen and validate and have insight (which I donâ€™t take up too much time to share yet bc Iâ€™m busy listening first!)

/Formal-Paperwork.title: Formal Paperwork
/Formal-Paperwork.content:
Proposal
MSA
SOW
Invoice


# Marketing / Sales

## Untargeted marketing

website

## Individual-targeted marketing

email to (the decision maker at the company for your service; eg the CTO or the HR training person) with what they might need

## "Pre-posal"

â€œhereâ€™s what you said you needâ€

â€œhereâ€™s what makes me uniquely equipped to helpâ€

â€œhereâ€™s how I can helpâ€

emailed + attached

## Proposal

similar to the pre-posal, but with prices?

(idk why Andrea doesnâ€™t call the pre-posal a proposal, all the clients seem to lol)

# Expectation Setting / Legal

## Expectations for Relationship

MSA Contract â€” contains late payment details etc

## Expectations for Current Work

SOW Contract

First SOW gets sent out with the MSA, same doc

# Money Terms

## Estimate

ballpark amount, pending info about detail

could be a range

e.g. â€œIt depends on the size of your org, or whether I do surveysâ€

could be in the Pre-posal/Proposal

## Quote

specific amount that wonâ€™t change for this specific, defined work

scope changes could trigger a change still of course

could be a fixed amount, or could be a rate

could be in the Pre-posal/Proposal

## Invoice

= bill; you owe me this much today, a specific amount

one SOW could have multiple invoices (e.g. if itâ€™s monthly)

should be attached to a SOW (current work expectations doc)

# Examples

## Brianâ€™s Design Work

-   Marketing Artifacts
    -   Introduction = existing relationship; no need for the marketing artifacts
    -   Agreement = requested something by email; reply with yes I can help
-   Expectation Setting Artifacts
    -   Relationship Expectations = implied
    -   Current Work Expectations = by email / implied
-   Payment Artifacts
    -   Expectation Setting = Quote
    -   Billing = Invoice

## Caseyâ€™s Usual Flow

-   Marketing Artifacts
    -   Introduction: opening with the targeted marketing to HR etc; linking to the website
    -   Agreement: Pre-posal â€œhereâ€™s what you said you needâ€
-   Expectation Setting Artifacts
    -   Relationship Expectations = MSA
    -   Current Work Expectations = SOW
-   Payment Artifacts
    -   Expectation Setting = Estimate in pre-posal
    -   Billing = Invoice, paid upfront, tied to SOW

/Getting-Clients.title: Getting Clients
/Getting-Clients.content:
### For someone to buy your service, they go through phases

AIDA

Aware = Are they aware of your service?

Interest = Are they interested? (do they have the problem?)

Desire = Do they desire this solution? (this solution?)

Action = Have they paid and showed up for it?

### Sales Funnel

A potential client could fall off at any phase - some % per phase

Sales funnelÂ spreadsheet example - itâ€™s numbers!

To get enough clients, itâ€™s a numbers game

[Example sales funnel spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/18w11rt2dG17CSMJm_1FAFYpcsbT2rB4HROZdWqSlaBA/edit#gid=0)

### Who is your target audience? Where are they?

For tech employees as an example

Social media: Often on Twitter or LinkedIn.

Online communities: Slack/Discord

In person events: Theyâ€™re also atÂ [Meetup.com](http://meetup.com/)Â events and conferences!

### How to get people into the funnel?

You donâ€™t have to use all of these, choose your strengths:

social media

referrals

networking

events

etc

### Connections

Most people start with connections!

-   your connections hiring you directly
-   your connectionsâ€™ companies hiring you
-   your connectionsâ€™ connections hiring you
-   your connectionsâ€™ connectionsâ€™ companies hiring you

### How to get people through the funnel?

Once you have a â€œleadâ€

Sales call techniques - listening, SPIN selling

people are immensely more likely to buy something to meet an explicit need they have - one they express explicitly

### Getting Started Is Tough

What can you say when someone ask â€œwho have you worked with?â€ but youâ€™re just getting started?? ğŸ˜¬

usually what they really want to know is â€œwhy should I believe you can do this?â€.

sometimes they mean â€œwhat sectors have you worked in? my sector is not like the others!â€ (like: private companies, government, consulting firms, nonprofits etc)

### Credibility

Eventually you can say â€œI have been paid to do this through my own company, here are past clientsâ€

In the meantime itâ€™s okay to list places youâ€™ve done related work with, even if it was before the inception of this company. YouÂ _do_Â have a lot of experience, and it counts!

you probably have pastÂ _experience_Â you can leverage.

### What if they find out Iâ€™m an imposter?

If you got the client, how confident are you that you could help with their problems?

Think of people youâ€™ve worked with who you were not impressed with â€” youâ€™re probably even above average! If youâ€™re just starting, you care a lot and have a lot to prove. Iâ€™m confident in you, even if I donâ€™t know you.

Sometimes my partner shares a horror story from a past company, and I love the way he punctuates them â€” he says â€œanyone can run a business!â€

Thatâ€™s... true! You can, too :)

### I want some initial clients

If not, or if you want more, you could do a client or two for cheaper or free. You could volunteer for a nonprofit in exchange for using them as case studies you share.

Beware not to let this trend continue for long though â€” you need less credibility like this than you might imagine. A lot of your success depends on your sales techniques.

## Lead Generation

I love doing public, free, community events anyway - Iâ€™ve been doing these for 10y!

These also happen to generate business leads for me lately. Event hosts are very generous at encouraging me to share my business materials, even when Iâ€™m shy to â€” they want quality content, and Iâ€™m a professional at that!

### building credibility

if you can â€” show, donâ€™t tell

do invest in people who â€œget itâ€ already â€” strong allies

### Trust

highest = own experience

next = experience of someone trusted (friend, coworker)

next = experience of someone kinda trusted (respected companies; certifications)

next = experience of someone not trusted (strangers on the internet)

lowest = what the salesperson says themselves

### Why connections are so powerful

friends, past coworkers, professional contacts

they have the highest level of trust (their own, direct experience)

they often have the 2nd level of trust (someone trusted) for a decision maker

### Competitive Analysis â€” How is the customer making their decisions?

What 3-6 factors are they considering? Which are more/less important? You can ask them that!

What factors are the most important? How would they rank them?

When someone is comfortable thinking in numbers, sometimes I ask them to say â€œdouble or half (or average)â€ for each of them.

Knowing this can help you know what to focus on with them

This can also help you decide how to strengthen your company and/or marketing materials, too!

[an example spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/18XikuteJR7cPnThLNzT7rkj1_pAFJ2UHpX8z2LdpL0o/edit?usp=sharing)

### Questions are more powerful than statements

â€œFrom what youâ€™ve seen, what would you say the strengths are of my company?â€

â€œIâ€™m stronger than competitors because REASONSâ€

### Weaknesses

Iâ€™m not sure about asking about weaknesses/concerns/hesitations directly â€” could move their focus somewhere you donâ€™t want them to focus

but itâ€™s probably good to address any glaring ones upfront, or be ready to address them

/Invoicing-Clients.title: Invoicing Clients
/Invoicing-Clients.content:
I bill them as a sole proprietor, and money goes directly to my personal bank account (through Stripeâ€™s intermediary one if they do ACH).

I send an Invoice (via Stripe) â€” it can be as simple as an email, although I like them to be PDF at least like Stripe does

Then they pay Stripeâ€™s ACH or they send me a check

I deposit it in my personal account

Before invoicing them I usually get them to sign a contract (MSA/SOW) with rates

Sometimes I skip a contract if itâ€™s small and/or I trust them â€” like my one off coaching clients who pay upfront anyway)

Some companies also ask for my SSN/EIN so they can give me a W-9 at the end of the year (but it doesnâ€™t matter to me if they do). Iâ€™ve been using SSN for the past two years since I didnâ€™t get set up with an EIN until this LLC (and thatâ€™s okay!) If a company doesnâ€™t deal with W-9 thatâ€™s okay and Iâ€™m still responsible for taxes on it (Quickbooks tracks this income) â€” I donâ€™t really care if they deal with it or not personally

/Legal-Structures-and-Taxes.title: Legal Structures and Taxes
/Legal-Structures-and-Taxes.content:
### Legal/Organizational Structures

Differences between Sole Proprietorship, LLC, S-Corp etc



### CRM

Hubspot

[Seanâ€™s powerpoint](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1gmcvJvoFWbHItCn1f3fmyZ6GNMKEolVb9wQypZrp_Hg/edit#slide=id.g24abaf8d29_0_91)

/Pricing-Your-Services.title: Pricing Your Services
/Pricing-Your-Services.content:
### pricing

per hour vs value-based

you can do per-hour to get started

The most common advice lately is to focus on value-based pricing â€” how much is the customer willing to pay to get the benefit?

### Who sets the price?

I like to ask â€œdo you have a budget for this?â€ Then there are two ways:

1.  If your group has a set budget already, I can tailor things I offer to fit that budget.
    
2.  If your group doesn't have a budget, then I can calculate price on my end. To calculate it, I need to know what we'd want to do ideally â€” we can talk through that together!
    

### Relative Importance of Cost/Budget

Not every client is equally concerned about budget

-   Two big factors are
    -   impact (can you do the work you promise? will it have the effect we want?)
    -   budget (how much will it cost?)
-   Size of company
    -   Companies tend to be less concerned about cost than individuals (my money vs someone elseâ€™s money)
    -   Larger companies tend to be less concerned about cost (more about: can I justify it to the right people?)
-   Individual motivations
    -   What motivates [this specific person who will decide to buy or not]?
        -   Motivated more by impact than cost savings? They may be seen as the person who brought in the help to solve this big problem!
        -   Motivated more by cost savings than impact? They may just have to â€œcover their basesâ€ â€” may be more focused on the highest value (impact divided by cost).
-   Multiple Budgets
    -   Many departments have their own budget â€” like:
        -   Each Engineering Manager may have a training budget
        -   HR may have a training budget for DEI training
        -   an ERG (employee resource group) may have its own budget
        -   Individuals may have their own training budget
    -   Any of these can potentially ask for more budget if itâ€™s motivated enough (and not every buyer realizes this power)

### Price Factors

I donâ€™t always share the nuances of how I calculate price with customers, but some are curious.

Some things that increase price:

-   my expertise in something
    -   could be that Iâ€™ve done it before
    -   could be that I can do it well anyway
-   more client-hours
-   more audience members (for talks/workshops)
-   custom work (my expertise + more non-client-hours)
    -   outcome is more important than polish overall
-   more non-client-hours (prep work; research; writing/documenting)
-   Intellectual Property â€” agree to let them record it (they can own the performance, but not my content)

Some things that decrease price:

-   bulk discounts (more services / more people included in services)
-   guaranteed testimonials (but you can get testimonials anyway!)
-   guaranteed feedback from them (but you can get feedback anyway!)
-   agree to recommend me to colleagues
-   association â€” agree to let me reference your company
-   agree to let me share anonymized content?

Some things that donâ€™t affect price

-   existing content (my expertise + itâ€™s polished content)
    -   good for me that I can re-use it! That doesnâ€™t affect them though

### 5 Câ€™s of Compensation

Andreaâ€™s 5 Câ€™s

-   Explicit
    -   Cash
    -   Connections â€” can they introduce me to new people? do they have a robust network?
        -   â€œintroduce me to 3 CTOsâ€
    -   Content â€” Is it public? Is it recorded â€” can I put it on a speaker reel? Is this a talk I want to develop? Beta testing it. Ask for feedback? Can I re-use this work?
-   Implicit
    -   Credibility â€” prestige of association
    -   Community â€” pro bono, doing good stuff want to help, meaning and impact

Examples

-   talk given before â€” just cash
-   Me EIT volunteering â€” community support, credibility of cofounder of the group, connections to leads, content development â€” not volunteering bc I get 4/5 of the Câ€™s

If theyâ€™re low on cash

-   Would I feel good doing this anyway? (community impact)
-   Would it be recorded and I own the performance?
-   Can this person introduce me to people?
-   If org agrees to (buy in bulk) to bring me in for others â€” Iâ€™ll toss this in for free
    -   eg â€œif you commit to 5 Iâ€™ll do a 2nd free oneâ€
    -   could be for womenâ€™s group but open to anyone
-   Public community event, hosted/sponsored by company (advertising/marketing budget)

### the power of discounts

minor discounts incentivize choices - when theyâ€™re on the fence (often!) people tend to go for the discount

bulk discounts - buy 10 sessions, get a discount % on them

upsell discounts - buy service x, and get some of service y too


### Pricing Techniques

I donâ€™t have an easy answer, but I have an approach you might like to use here! â€œRachetingâ€

## Racheting
I HAVE set my cost too high before and lots clients by following the common advice â€œcharge more.â€ Usually Iâ€™d rather have these clients for sure for now and build out my portfolio and references and network â€” and getting to my goal price is a secondary goal.I call this technique â€œratcheting,â€ like the tool that tightens in one direction.Ratcheting is basically raising my price for each client so I can learn the boundaries. My goal price is in the range (â€œsweet spotâ€) between â€œclient hesitates but does payâ€ and â€œclient declines.â€ (sometimes I can turn a decline around somehow, but thatâ€™s a different story).I â€œratchetâ€ up the price until I have a sense of where the upper limit is for a certain type of client. This upper limit varies by industry, by size of company etc â€” I try to keep those factors in mind too.

If youâ€™re starting out with a new service or new type of client you could â€œbootstrapâ€ this search in the price-space by trying out different rates with different clients and seeing reactions â€” like 200/h, 250/h, 300/h, 350/h etc.

This is searching the space of what theyâ€™ll pay, as opposed to what you would like to getÂ paid. Itâ€™s totally useful to know what you want to get paid too! But it doesnâ€™t necessarily inform you of what clients will pay

## Rule of Thumb
Iâ€™ve heard a rule of thumb that a freelancer rate is in the ballpark of some number multiplied by your base rate â€” x2 seems low to me, maybe it was x2.5 or x3 even?

Although I think that piece of advice is really to shift your mindset more than an actual â€œbased-on-data what-people-will-payâ€ sort of thing.

## Commodity vs Specialty
Another big difference in pricing is if youâ€™re doing a â€œcommodityâ€ service (easy to find an alternative) or a â€œspecialtyâ€ service (hard/impossible to find an equivalent alternative). Specialty services can charge a lot more than commodity services. Specialization is powerful, and a lot of advice focuses on that -- but that doesnâ€™t mean that offering a commodity service isnâ€™t a valid option. Most services are probably more of a commodity!

/Tools.title: Tools
/Tools.content:
Notion, Quickbooks, Google Business, Stripe Invoicing, Stripe Atlas, Mercury Bank, Obsidian, Reclaim.ai, Calendly, Mailtrack.io, Whereby, Teachable, Gumroad, Etsy, Printful, Namecheap, super.so, webflow, Lu.ma,Â [ko-fi.com](http://ko-fi.com/), Google Analytics, Hotjar, Affinity Designer, Descript

  

I use Notion (itâ€™s like Google docs + a database) to track time worked and to track leads/deals, and to track individuals (like a CRM)

I use Intuit Quickbooks Self-Employed to track expenses and taxes

I use Google for Business for my business email and Google docs

I use Stripe Invoicing to send [invoices](Invoicing%20Clients.md) (usually locked down to ACH only, so I donâ€™t lose a ton on credit card fees - and half my clients send e-checks anyway and thatâ€™s fine too)
[Invoicing Clients](Invoicing%20Clients.md)

I registered my business with Stripe Atlas - I was in a big hurry so Iâ€™m thankful for it. Iâ€™d probably register directly with the state even though itâ€™s more work if I wasnâ€™t in a hurry. Iâ€™m still working as a sole proprietorship lately, I havenâ€™t billed anyone as my LLC yet.

I use Mercury bank for my business bank account

I donâ€™t have business insurance yet but I plan to eventually

I use Obsidian to take notes lately and keep a daily log

I use Reclaim.ai to sync my several work calendarsÂ 

I use Calendly to have appointment slots open for people to schedule time with me

I use Mailtrack.io to track email opens (it even works on mobile as a gmail plugin too! Thatâ€™s a big feature to me)

I use Whereby for video calls with better breakout rooms, for workshops

I use Teachable (soon hopefully!) for selling online courses

I use Gumroad to sell digital things (my ebook/audiobook)

I use Etsy to sell physical things, wired up to Printful.com to print/ship them

I use Namecheap to buy/manage web domains

I use super.so to host my Happy and Effective website (it styles some Notion pages, so I can edit content in Notion)

I use webflow to host my book websiteÂ [debuggingyourbrain.com](http://debuggingyourbrain.com/)Â (all custom designed)

I use Lu.ma to host events (a free Eventbrite alternative)

I useÂ [ko-fi.com](http://ko-fi.com/)Â to accept donations (like after a free workshop)

I use Google Analytics to track website traffic

I use Hotjar to record website browsing behavior (scrolling, mouse, etc)

I use Affinity Designer to design web graphics for events and visuals for blog posts etc (itâ€™s like Illustrator but not Adobe and not subscription based)

I use Descript to edit videos and make subtitles and audiograms for videos
